question: Klute. With a K. K - L - U -
answer: Are you with plant security, Sergeant?

question: Town Police.
answer: Then how are you involved?

question: I know Tom Grunemann.
answer: You knew the subject Thomas Grunemann. How well?

question: We grew up together. Kids.
answer: Can you account for his disappearance in any way?

question: No.
answer: Did he recently appear to you agitated or depressed? -- indicates no -- Did he voice to you grievance or discontent with his research work here? Indicates no. Moral or sexual problems or peculiarities? --

question: No.
answer: Marital problems in general? Indicates possibly -- am I right Sergeant?

question: Everybody's got some, I guess.
answer: Did he ever mention specifically a girl or woman in New York?

question: No.
answer: Examine this letter please. We recovered that from the shredder -- the plant disposal and incinerator system. Grunemann apparently typed it Friday, before he left, decided not to send it, tossed it away. We've already contacted the New York Police; they think they know the girl in question. He never mentioned this type thing to you? You didn't know he had these interests?

question: It looks like he sent her quite a few of those Holly -- the girl -- she recalls six or seven letters like --
answer: -- has disclosed no evidence of crime or criminal intent within the jurisdiction of this bureau, and since subject Thom --

question: The subject got emotionallv disturbed; he just dropped out. There's thousands.
answer: Inspector we understand your position; ours is a little different. We have an investment in Tom Grunemann. The Company has an investment, and we feel entitled to investigate for ourselves.

question: Private investigation, you mean. Yes sir, of course you're entitled, and there's some very competent --
answer: Klute offered us his services; we've accepted. Klute knew Tom. He has a great many ideas about the case --

question: Yes sir, we know he --
answer: We'd expect him to work in cooperation with you. He'd report to each of you and to our Company's New York office, to Pete -- Pete goes there on a regular schedule back and forth, and --

question: Bree Daniel, any messages? OK, thanks. Trina? Bree. Do I? Oh no, just a commercial I thought I might get, that's all. Well I'd take a quick thirty, hon. Do you have a commuter for me? Wait. Hullo. Ooh, I knew I'd like you. Lover, that's got to be a little extra. I mean it sounds very exciting, what you speak of, you've got me all excited. But something special like that, you know it's got to cost a little more, mm? Oh lover, oh it's too much -- oh you thrill me -- yes, like that, it's -- oh it's beautiful, oh -- What is it?
answer: Miss Daniel? My name is Klute -- John Klute -- Can I talk to you?

question: What about?
answer: My name's John Klute.

question: You said that.
answer: I'm an investigator. I'd like to ask you some questions about Tom Grunemann.

question: Who?
answer: Tom Grunemann. He wrote you some letters.

question: Gee.
answer: He was a research engineer at the Tuscarora Laboratories in Pennsylvania. He disappeared from there last April. I've been hired to look for him.

question: Why?
answer: You know what I'm talking about. Miss Daniel.

question: Honest?
answer: Will you let me ask you some questions?

question: Dew yew hayuv ah-dentifikyshun? You're not police or FBI; you're just a private investigator?
answer: Mm.

question: And you just want to ask me a few questions?
answer: Mm.

question: Bree Daniel. Yeah, hi hon.
answer: Oh hon, I just don't know. I'm trying to stay out of it.

question: Marta, thanks, and I'd love to party with you hon, but --
answer: Well try to get someone else Marty and if I change my mind -- sure hon, bye.

question: Bree Daniel, Caucasian, twenty eight, good physical health, no narcotics record, presenting an unusually strong personality some ways, high intelligence, a high bracket call girl. -- Usual case history -- this isn't a medical confidence, it's all of them -- broken family, lonely, confused, crummy childhood, early promiscuity, formal prostitution beginning in her teens, income twenty-five to thirty thousand a year. Oh they don't keep the money
answer: I want to know how Tom Grunemann got mixed up in it.

question: Not unusual.
answer: Did she talk about him to you?

question: About his letters -- that's all she remembered. Quite violent material, I'd say, obsessive, a quite sick man. But that's not unusual either.
answer: Has she talked with you since prison?

question: No. She had every good intention of it -- coming to me as a private patient, getting out of the life, devoting herself to an acting career.
answer: I think she's trying that.

question: Marta -- Hi. Bree. Hi. Well I could come over tonight - if you'd like -- if there's no one else. I really want to just talk to you. Hi? -_ Oh -- You scared me, Mr. Faber.
answer: Good material, not too good cut. I'd do better for you.

question: Oh thank you.
answer: Enjoy. Well --

question: It's good to see you. Well -- could we do it first and then just talk?
answer: Sure dear, yes.

question: Well -- well I'm just back. And -- I must tell you -- something quite wonderful.
answer: Yes?

question: And Cannes was quite fun, quite; and we played baccarat and chemindefer and there was a nice little Italian marquis quite enthusiastic for me -- but a young man can be so silly --
answer: Mm.

question: And then one night -- at the gaming tables -- well I just saw him. A stranger -- looking at me -- and I knew suddenly that all my life I'd been -- -- May I? It's so --
answer: Please --

question: Not young; he wasn't young -- gray at the temples, he -- well actually he looked like you.
answer: Yes?

question: And nobody could tell me who he was -- an exiled prince or a mercenary or a bullfighter or -- but I felt it stirring inside me, this -- this wild, pagan feeling -- And next day at the beach -- our beach pavilion -- I saw him again, his eyes burning into me. I was helpless. Without his even speaking to me, without his even touching, I knew that somehow -- somehow --
answer: Klute watches in that direction a moment longer. In his expression a certain curiosity -- a prurience -- but rather more strongly, disappointment, a measure of disgust. Not his affair. He turns away from it, into camera, and --

question: Whyn't you just cut out? Oh you bastard. Is it the shakedown hon? You picked a loser, I just don't have it.
answer: No, I'm look --

question: If I was taking calls full time would I be living in this kip? I'd be back on Park Avenue; I could support the whole National Guard!
answer: Could I ask some questions?

question: Or you'll get me shoved back in the brig you mean; another month with the bull-dykes. Look, I told the police everything They showed me that one. I understand it's Grunemann, but I told them, I just don't remember. A family sort of man.
answer: -- Tom, again. Company outing or picnic or something like that.

question: Isn't that sweet. Well it could be any one of them bubi; I get to see them all. Look -- please -- will you just try to get it from my side? A year ago. I was in the life fulltime. I was living on Park with leather furniture and a million dresses. Then they dropped on me, the fuzz, they caged me -- they started asking me about a man, some man, I'm supposed to have seen a year before that. Two years ago, two. He could be in Yemen! A name. Grunemann. Nothing. And they showed me pictures like this and they meant nothing. Then they asked me, well had I been getting letters, from someone out there in Cabbageville --
answer: -- Tuscarora --

question: All right, yes, I had been. Those sick, wild letters -- I'm watching you, gonna follow you, gonna punish you, kill you et cetera. Well, they said, all right that's Grunemann. So try to remember when you and he - when -- well I don't know, there was that dumper once, he sounded like that dumper -- Dumpers; they get their kicks beating you up. A man hired me once, then tried to really kill me - that'd be about two years ago. OK Tommy-baby, Allie-Allie-in-free kid, I got the gumdrops. You remind me of my uncle.
answer: What? What do you remember about that -- dumper?

question: Nothing. Except he wasn't kidding. Usually it's a fakeout, you probably know. They pretend to tie you up, and you wear a dress with a cloth belt and they pretend to whip you or you -- Hell it's their money. I'll hang from the shower rod and whistle Maytime. Except this guy was really tripped out on it; he --
answer: But you can't say that Dumper was Tom Grunemann.

question: I can't say he was anybody! So -- OK -- that's all? Well could I have them back now hon? -- those tape recordings you've got downstairs -- OK? -- and if you want you can have a good time and I'll have a good time and--
answer: What about everything since? Everything that's happened since Tom Grunemann disappeared. The phone calls and the --

question: Just phone calls, right? They ring, you answer, they don't say anything, just blank. Kids getting kicks. Burglars looking for an empty apartment. I mean there is nothing that proves --
answer: What about the other things you've reported? -- -- being followed on the --

question: Look -- I'm sorry -- I've led everybody wrong. I mean yes, I get those feelings, but that's just me, that's just feelings. I'm sure this will amuse you; I'm scared of the dark. And sometimes I get shook up, I hear people or -- well, I'll come out in the morning and think someone's been prying at my mailbox, or there's a little -- trash outside my door and I wonder if someone left it there for -- do you see? -- things other people wouldn't even notice. Well that's not real, it's just nerves; it's got nothing to do with -- Bree Daniel. Oh yes, Ted Carlin, how is Ted? Oh, well, thank you very much but maybe the next time you're in town? Well I just love Ted and I'd love to meet you -- you have a very nice voice -- but I just -- Well I'm having a chat with a very nice cop. Actually not a real cop; he's a private inves --
answer: Is that how you get most of your dates? Someone gives your name to someone else?

question: Most of them.
answer: Is that how you met the Dumper? -- Someone else gave --

question: How would I remember?
answer: How else do you meet them? Pimps?

question: You're very square. Pimps don't get you dates, cookie; they just take the money.
answer: I have some names the police gave me. Frank Ligourin. Will you tell me what --

question: Look, I'm sure this'll amuse you too. Ilia trying to get away from all that.
answer: What about the old gentleman the other night, Mr. Faber?

question: You saw that, goddamn you? You saw it? He's seventy. His wife's dead. He started cutting garments at fourteen. His whole life, he's maybe had a week's vacation, I'm all he has and he never, never touches me, and what harm in it, what -- Klute, tell me, what's your bag? Are you a talker, or a button man or a doubler, or maybe you like them very young -- children -- or get your chest walked around with high-heeled shoes, or have us watch you tinkle? Or -- -- You want to wear women's clothes, or you get off ripping things -- -- you perverted hypocrite square bastards. Gee I hope this doesn't make my cold any worse.
answer: Tell me about Frank Ligourin.

question: Mm? Oh, he was my old man. We broke up.
answer: When? When did you and Ligourin break up? Mind not doing that?

question: What? This?
answer: -- OK?

question: I thought you could trick me for those tapes. Don't you get lonely in that little green room? Or let me get you someone; I have terrific friends, wild.
answer: No thanks.

question: Gee. I've had men pay two hundred dollars for me -- here, you're turning down a freebie. You can get a perfectly good dishwasher for that. You've changed your mind? You do want to play?
answer: I don't want you to look up. There's someone on the skylight. Easy -- pretend you're looking here- -- here. Now I'm going to walk around -- you just keep talking, straight through, straight through. Tell me about acting -- what are you doing tomorrow -- where do you go?

question: I go on rounds.
answer: Rounds, what are they? -- don't watch me, keep talking.

question: You go see agents -- or Equity calls, open casting calls. And ad agencies -- commercials -- you don't get work, you just go around. And they're always polite -- show people -- they say thank you very much. You lie there covered with blood, smiling, they say --
answer: I couldn't get him. It's all right.

question: Well do you think it was him?
answer: What do you think?

question: Can't you get him?
answer: Maybe, if you tell me the things you haven't.

question: You asked me where I got that date with the dumper -- Frank sent me on it.
answer: Do you know where he got the dumper?

question: He never told me.
answer: Well, let's go down and ask him.

question: What did you expect? Frankie still has a good string, three girls. Figure three hundred a week from each.
answer: Is that what you gave him?

question: Bree -- hi -- come in, come in.
answer: Frank -- Klute.

question: Hi. Come in. I was just catching up some work -- mocking up the photographs. I used to be a photographer myself - Bree tell you? -- Before I got in the publishing.
answer: Frank, he knows you're a pimp. He knows you were my pimp.

question: Well Bree, maybe you'd rather -- How's it been? With me Bree it's eternally the same. Toward you. I guess you know that.
answer: Yeah Frank, I know that.

question: I've always respected Bree. I'd like to make something clear.
answer: I've just got a few --

question: I'd like to make something clear. I don't go after a girl; a girl comes to me. Her choice. Right?
answer: I'm looking for a man. Tom Grunemann. Bree thinks he may have been the dumper -- that call she had two years ago. She says you sent her on it.

question: Two years ago? Sorry.
answer: They tell me you use narcotics. Could I bring someone around to look at your arms?

question: Look -- dad -- I may stand better with the cops than you. OK, a family matter. Between the girls. I had two other cows -- -- two other girls besides Bree.
answer: She told me.

question: OK and one of them Jane McKenna -- she blows a little jealous of Bree - you know? -- Bree comes first? And evidently she knew the freak --- that he was a dumper -- she conned me into passing him to Bree, you know, so Bree'd get hurt. I didn't know. Till afterwards.
answer: Why didn't you tell Bree, afterwards?

question: You don't tell them. That one of their own in-laws laid a dumper on them? Peace in the family. Beyond that, I don't know. All she wrote.
answer: I'd like to talk with Jane McKenna.

question: Did you like my friend Frankie?
answer: No.

question: Didn't he tell you what you wanted?
answer: It didn't go anywhere. But that's not why --

question: About the dumper, didn't he tell you that?
answer: It was Jane McKenna who sent you the dumper.

question: Well -- she's dead. I thought you were going back to the apartment.
answer: You said you wanted these.

question: Oh golly, oh just what I've always dreamed of, dirty phone calls. How come?
answer: You told me what you could. I guess I'm through with your part of it.

question: Is there anything more I could --
answer: I don't see anything, do you?

question: What're you gonna do next?
answer: Try some other ways.

question: What do I do meanwhile? -- wait for that clown to fall through the skylight on me?
answer: And I don't think that was Tom.

question: You said it was!
answer: No, I said what did you think.

question: Oh -- wait -- oh I get it. You said that just to keep me scared. So I'd tell you everything I -- oh clever; oh you smart, tricky hick.
answer: Well --

question: Hey, but did we get to you, Klute? A little?
answer: Yeah, you got to me.

question: -- Us city folks? The sin, the glitter, the wickedness?
answer: Oh. No. Not that way. I'd say it was more -- I don't know -- -- too bad? Pathetic?

question: Goodbye. What the hell do you mean, pathetic?
answer: It's kind of late.

question: It got lonely upstairs. There's someone on the roof. Oh, don't be a doo-doo.
answer: Not much point to this, is there?

question: Ezra, I'm lots better than you're used to. Tell me -- the other night, watching me with Mr. Faber -- wasn't your tongue a little bit hanging out?
answer: Mm.

question: So you're not too different from him, or the chap on the roof, or Tommy-baby -- Look, if you don't use it somebody else just will. And you've done your whole bit with me, your entire duty, and so now this is my thing. So enjoy, Mr. Faber would say, enjoy.
answer: Bree -- thanks -- I don't want to.

question: Oh don't be all hypocrite. Or do you really like other kicks? Is it more just having power over someone? -- so you don't really need to -- Who the hell are you, buttoning me up? I knew it, I knew it, a killer. Oh lover -- oh you thrill me -- oh, it's beautiful -- oh yes, yes -- oh like that, like that, yes -- What's the matter hon? You were great. Terrific. A tiger.
answer: Thanks.

question: Well what're you down about? You mean because you didn't get me there? You can't expect that. I mean Frank, yes, he'd get me there all the time -- but never with a John. And I'm sorry I can't stay and learn your special little games. And I certainly don't want you to feel bad about this -- losing your virtue all of a sudden -- because I sort of knew you would. As I said, like everyone, right? Besides - you can always tell yourself you made me come downstairs. Ta, luv. -- Why? Why -- please, why? -- Why lose, why look? Why hate and give and want and love? Why get, grieve, g -- -- gug -- gug -- Why? -- I want to know what.
answer: You asked if there was anything more you could help me with.

question: When?
answer: I've checked the records of Jane McKenna's death -- I can't get anything special. But Frank Ligourin had another girl you said, besides McKenna and you.

question: Arlyn Page.
answer: Did she and Jane McKenna know each other?

question: Frankie kept them in the same apartment
answer: Then maybe Arlyn Page knew the Dumper too.

question: Arlyn had a very big habit - heroin - she's the one who started Frank. She's strung out now; you won't find her.
answer: You could help me find her. You know the people. I'll pay you a hundred dollars.

question: I can make that in a lunch break! Look, Hiram, you're sure it isn't just me? -- you decided you liked it, after all, the other night; you'll hang around for seconds?
answer: Don't worry.

question: Joanie -- Mike, hi -- Hi Pat. A new daddy. I'n he cute? Trina this is Klute. I told you about him. Uh uh. Trina honey, he just wants to find Arlyn Page. She was with you after she left Frank. Gil?
answer: I'm not looking for her personally - someone she might know about. Do you know where she went? Have you heard from her recently? Have you heard from her recently? Do you know where she went from here? Was she living with a man? What's the matter?

question: What the hell do you think's the matter. I could wait for you someplace.
answer: If Arlyn Page is living with Tom Grunemann --

question: -- Then you don't need me.
answer: But if it's someone else I do.

question: Honey, a couple of years ago, with Jane and Frankie? -- Jane sent me a Dumper --
answer: Please, if he sees you, he won't come!

question: Arlyn, just tell me, did Jane have a dumper, one of her regular Johns?
answer: What about him? Yes.

question: Did he come around often?
answer: No. He was an older man hon. The dumper was older.

question: Please, I am begging you.
answer: It's important.

question: That's not the Dumper, that's all! He was an older man!
answer: Can you give me any more description than that?

question: I believed her
answer: All right, suppose it wasn't Tom Grunemann; where does that get you?

question: It's where it doesn't get me. I've got nothing left that connects to anything.
answer: Then, close the case.

question: I better keep looking.
answer: Where, how?

question: I could try Arlyn Page again. She saw much more of the Dumper than Bree Daniel.
answer: You just finished telling me she had nothing to offer. Not Tom, you said, the Dumper was clearly not Tom.

question: It's got to make sense some way.
answer: Yes Evvie, thanks. Gentlemen, I'm sorry. I'm flying back out to Pennsylvania Friday; I'll fill them in on things.

question: How is it back there?
answer: I think you're homesick. I'll be out at my camp over the weekend. Nice right now, that touch of fall in the air, that skim of frost in the early mornings, very peaceful. John, I'll be back here again Thursday; I'll be in touch. Lieutenant, thank you.

question: Arlyn Page was probably an alias. She went by the names Terry Arlyn and June Price. She may have been from Pittsburgh, someone told me. I can give you a list of people who knew her, if that would help to -- Is he claiming the body?
answer: Man could you help me?

question: Yeah, what?
answer: You know, help me out. That's my baby there, dead. I got to get up. Man you don't know what that does to me, my baby dead --

question: -- You've got to get up.
answer: Yeah.

question: Well hello -- come on in.
answer: I thought you ought to know, Arlyn Page is dead.

question: How?
answer: The same as Jane McKenna.

question: Thanks for the jolly news. I thought maybe you'd left town by now. You kind of just disappeared. But you boys from Tuscarora have a habit of disappearing, don't you?
answer: The next few weeks I would like to know where you are all the time.

question: Why?
answer: Just let me know when you are going out and where --

question: What if i go out on tricks - you wanna come along? You could sit and read the National Geographic.
answer: How can you do it to yourself?

question: I don't get you.
answer: Ligourin

question: I told you before, you wouldn't understand.
answer: You're right, I don't understand. Explain it to me. You were scared. Arlyn Page, that scared you. Well it should; that's death. So what did you do, you ran straight for it, death. Ligourin kills women.

question: No.
answer: No, no you're right, I'm sorry. He uses women; he lets them kill themselves. Is that how you want it?

question: Arlyn was a junkie; I'm not on junk!
answer: No, you can find some other way. Explain it to me. Bree, show me any sense to --

question: You get the Christ out! You dumb stupid bastard, you don't know anything, you square, you get out! I don't have to show you anything; you get out! If I asked you something, would you not laugh? -- asked you to look at something? I thought it was maybe changing shape or something. Look -- I hate everybody; and I'm sorry for everybody; and I'm scared all the time. Look, I don't know either. It's like the only thing I know how to do -- I feel safe.
answer: It's been a full day.

question: Please.
answer: We did this before.

question: No. Well all right. But you want to and I want you to and we both know it and all right.
answer: I don't like getting splashed. --- Bree --- Go back to sleep.

question: I'm still scared. I mean different but still. Look, I made it very clear from the start, you're a yokel, you don't excite me, you don't even interest me, and so I only have one question which is what the hell are you doing in my bed?
answer: My bed.

question: Oh! I am scared. The things I do. The things I could do to you.
answer: Mm.

question: No, not just 'mm'. You don't know what I -- Oh boy, say, you think you're pretty good.
answer: Yup.

question: Oh -- The son of a bitch seduced me! I know
answer: I'd just be guessing.

question: Guess!
answer: Maybe this wasn't just a trick. Maybe you're in danger of real love, real involve --

question: I do not love him.
answer: You've spent your life avoiding this. You'll try hard to deny it; you're quite likely to destroy it.

question: All right. Loneliness. Well -- separated. From other people. Forgotten. Well, as if I can be here, I can go through the motions, right? But the truth is, I don't belong.
answer: Don't belong?

question: Do you always have to repeat?
answer: Sorry.

question: Well it's more than loneliness. Hate. People hating me -- and watching me and following and waiting to hurt me -- you know? I'm all screwed up.
answer: You think people hate you.

question: The truth is I hate them
answer: Didn't want you.

question: Think this is our guy?
answer: I don't know. It looks familiar to me.

question: Thought it might. It's off an arrest report you typed two years ago. Man you wanted samples of everybody. Now the next cat. Mm?
answer: But what reason could he have? What possible reason?

question: Unless he was involved with Grunemann's disappearance.
answer: I knew Tom never wrote that letter.

question: What else do you know?
answer: I never could believe that Tom was a split personality. I never believed he was a Dumper; and I don't believe he disappeared of his own volition; and I don't believe he's alive.

question: We have some very tentative circumstantial evidence of freeky behavior, but there's no evidence of murder - there's not even a body.
answer: I don't believe Tom's alive. But why? Why? Yes, Mr. Cable's office, please.

question: I don't believe Tom's alive. But why? Why? Yes, Mr. Cable's office, please.
answer: John, how are you?

question: I'll be sending you on a report tonight.
answer: It's a beautiful day in Tuscarora - I don't envy you that humidity in the city.

question: It's not so bad. Would you like to know what's in it? The report.
answer: What's in it?

question: I think Tom Grunemann's dead. I've been a lot of places - I've asked a lot of people. I've found no proof he's around. I've found no proof he was ever around. He could've been murdered.
answer: I'm sure the FBI and the Police explored that possibility.

question: No. They never did, really. But that's what I'm going to recommend. The next step. Unless something --
answer: Have you discussed this with them?

question: It's in the report.
answer: Do they have the report? Have you discussed it with them?

question: I wanted to give it to you first.
answer: All right. All right -- John, just sit tight will you? I'll read your report, I'll discuss it with the others. I'll be back next Thursday, we'll talk the whole thing over then. Nothing til Thursday, all right?

question: All right.
answer: Thank you. Goodbye, John.

question: Goodbye, Pete. He was always at their house on holidays. Tom and Holly always had him, over on holidays. Tom felt sorry for him - his whole life was work. Tom felt sorry for him.
answer: I saw Mr. Faber. You remember Mr. Faber, don't you?

question: Yeah.
answer: Is that all you have to say?

question: What am I supposed to say?
answer: Well, I told him I wouldn't - uh - go there any more. I know it's tough to understand, but it wasn't easy. You see, he was nice to me. I mean, it wasn't just him. I got something out of it too I guess. Anyway, I told him I wouldn't go there anymore.

question: Well, here's your gold star.
answer: Spangler says we have a relationship.

question: What?
answer: You and I -- a relationship.

question: I was wondering what that was.
answer: Hell there's nothing so mysterious about the square life. Oh Jesus. Oh Jesus.

question: Don't touch anything.
answer: You suppose he's a married fella?

question: He stands, looking down, taking no notice as --
answer: He got in my clothing! Oh. Oh. Oh look what he did in them.

question: Drop it. Stay out of there. Listen to me
answer: My God, I thought it was over. And here I am, daddy, right back at the start.

question: Bree --
answer: Right back at the start, right?

question: Go down in my room.
answer: You said it was over, right? You said not to worry any more, all over, right?

question: Can't. Yet. Oh we got everythin' else
answer: That's the reason i told him we had no evidence Tom was still alive. We wanted to shake him into another phone call or another letter. It didn't work out just that way.

question: Gov, want to leave me that one. How come he got to play with this one, anyway.
answer: I left them here. I was doing some work here.

question: It's damn lucky you didn't have the dossier on Cable here.
answer: Nobody's seen that.

question: Ah, Schmendrick -- what's the scam?
answer: Those were police laboratory people, they've been over the apartment.

question: Oh zippidy-doo, they'll find my fingerprints. Can I go in? I need some stuff.
answer: Where'd you spend last night?

question: With Trina.
answer: I called Trina.

question: Maybe I wasn't there when you called.
answer: Bree, what's actually happened? It wasn't that bad.

question: How do you know how bad it was?
answer: Why couldn't you stay here with me?

question: Because I didn't want to be touched! I didn't think you'd get that!
answer: Trask wants to talk with you.

question: Hey -- look officer -- I can explain everything. It was just -- you know, everything all of a --
answer: Trask wants to talk with you.

question: Miss Daniel, be sensible, you find another place till we get things cleaned up.
answer: Oh well that shouldn't take you more than another, oh, two and a half or three years, should it?

question: A few more days. We know who did this.
answer: So do I.

question: No, not Grunemann. He's dead. The man that killed him -- also prob'ly Jane McKenna, also Arlyn Page.
answer: Arlyn and Jane commited suicide. He said they commited suicide.

question: Now there's a picture I'd like you to --
answer: You said someone killed them, you said you know who, you said that.

question: Well we're pretty --
answer: Why isn't he locked up?

question: We don't want to just lock him up; we want a conviction, we wanted him to do something more.
answer: Is that why Klute didn't tell me?

question: I guess he figured it was better.
answer: What was better? I made better bait?

question: No, that's not --
answer: Is that what he set me up for? Everything he's told me from the beginning? -- don't worry, don't --

question: From the beginning I don't know why the hell he's messin with you. If he was me he'd know better. If he was even a city boy he'd know better. You're a whore Miss Daniel, that's the truth of it, right? Now somethin I'd like you to look at.
answer: I don't have to look at anything. I don't have --

question: Here please.
answer: Oh no.

question: Like for you to look for the man.
answer: Grunemann? I've looked at him a --

question: No. Not Grunemann. The Dumper. Just look around -- I said look for the Dumper.
answer: Oh! --

question: Sorry we had to meet here. But I'm pressed for time.
answer: Well there's a couple --

question: I read your report. I had to go along with it -- the idea of this being a wild goose chase, Tom being nowhere around --
answer: Well as a matter of --

question: I've been up country, you know my summer place, my camp. I don't even have a telephone there. This morning they sent a messenger out, that you'd been trying to call me.
answer: Yeah.

question: I'm on my way to Chicago. Very important meeting tonight. Well -- any new developments?
answer: Yeah, two things Pete, that --

question: You said Trask was arranging laboratory work. Police laboratory. Anything from that?
answer: Yeah. It wasn't Tom.

question: I'm sorry. I don't understand.
answer: It wasn't Tom that broke in the room.

question: It has to be Tom. You said he ripped up his own pictures, he --
answer: Not Tom. Whoever it was left a kind of souvenir, I told you, in her clothing. Semen. The laboratory got a blood group reading from that. The man was blood type 0; Tom was an AB.

question: Some mistake perhaps that --
answer: No. No mistake Pete. It doesn't prove who it was -- but proves it wasn't Tom.

question: You must be discouraged.
answer: Not too bad. This brings back that Dumper in the picture.

question: That who?
answer: Dumper, the man Bree Daniel mentioned and Arlyn Page knew and Jane McKenna knew.

question: You said he was no possible connection with Tom. The Page girl told you that, not Tom.
answer: Someone's been doing all these things.

question: You were hired to look for Tom, not someone.
answer: Pete, I've got a chance to buy Jane McKenna's black book.

question: What?
answer: Call-girls generally keep a book, you know, a list of their clients. Sometimes, if a girl retires, she'll even sell it worth good money. Jane McKenna had a black book; when she died it was stolen. I've been after it a long time.

question: You were hired to look for Tom.
answer: I'm meeting a man tomorrow night. He wants to meet me on East-River Drive -- he wants five hundred dollars for the book. Can you get that for me Pete?

question: I can't follow you.
answer: Will the Company put up five hundred dollars to get Jane McKenna's list of clients?

question: No. It's ridiculous. This has nothing to do with Tom Grunemann.
answer: It probably has the Dumper's name. It might give us some kind of new lead. I want a look at it anyhow.

question: Klute, the Company's interest is Tom Grunemann. Solely and exclusively. You say you can't find Tom; all right, I'll see that you're paid off; the case is closed.
answer: All right, but I'm going to see that list.

question: Why would they deal with you? You don't know these people.
answer: No, but Bree does. She's negotiating for me. Bree Daniel.

question: I can talk it over; possibly I can get the money. When are you meeting the man?
answer: Tomorrow evening, nine. East River Drive and 73rd Street.

question: Suppose I meet you there a half hour before.
answer: Just send me a money order.

question: No, I'd -- like to be in on it.
answer: Well --

question: Tomorrow. See you tomorrow night.
answer: Bree?

question: Mrs. Daniel -- -- I have to close up now. Leave your name and number with his message service, Mrs. Daniel, and why don't you just go home and wait until he --
answer: No.

question: Well I have to close up now.
answer: Look -- could I use your phone?

question: Yes indeed.
answer: Look. I almost killed my -- I almost killed someone.

question: Well I'm certain Doctor Spangler will want to talk with you; excuse me.
answer: Is Mr. Faber there? Mr. Faber Senior. -- I'm -- I just have to talk to someone. I'm just a little way across town --

question: Can't we talk together reasonably, just -- ordinarily? I know you're expecting some kind of -- extravagant behavior, but believe me -- do you believe me? --
answer: Yes -- all right --

question: -- We can talk --
answer: -- Yes.

question: All right, then, an ordinary matter. I'm a quite well off man, I have a -- position to respect. I would feel personally uncomfortable to be connected with a -- certain kind of woman, I'm sure you understand. Do you? Well I'd like to buy Jane McKenna's book. Her black book, Jane McKenna's, her list of -- of persons. I was told you're negotiating for it on behalf of -- That was what Klute told me -- you were negotiating for him to buy that list. And I'm in a position to pay a good deal more for it than he can. Do you understand? I'd like you to acquire it on my -- Miss Daniel, do you not understand? Miss Daniel, I can't tell whether you understand me. Is this something Klute just invented? Is this a trap for me, Miss Daniel; does Klute know about me? You have no idea what I'm talking about.
answer: Yes -- Jane McKenna's book -- I could make a phone call.

question: No, you're frightened, you're pretending. Well -- Klute knows about me then. Does everybody know, can you tell me?
answer: Yes.

question: Then it doesn't matter what I do any more, does it? You people know nothing about pain. I've got no idea what I shall do. I'm not going to hurt you, absolutely, I'm not.
answer: Will you let me go then?

question: It puzzles me so badly. I've done terrible things but I can't consider myself a terrible man. I've killed three people and I'd still want to say it was accident, do you see?
answer: If you'll let me go I could tell them what --

question: Tom Grunemann discovered me -- we were here on business together, he discovered me with Jane McKenna. Then I suppose it was the -- the contempt I saw in his face and the certainty that sooner or later he'd use it against me. Within the Company. I endured that as long as I could, do you see?
answer: I'm sorry, I'm just frightened. Yes.

question: Excuse me Miss Daniel?
answer: I said yes, I see.

question: Oh no, I don't think --
answer: Tell me. I'll listen. I just want you to tell me.
